comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I know lots about it ... I collected a series of photos that show it gradually being whittled away to nothing ... I have talked about it on another flickr image somewhere ages ago ... will have to find it. There is a CoSA demolition image that shows it when it was just storage for a timber merchant. It was the site of the first Sydney Council meetings

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Oh goodie! Whatever it (the domed building) was it does not show on this 1873 panorama from the Town Hall - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=913097#, so it must have had a short life.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Yes am trying to figure out what that is ...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363533740/ another pic of the Carrington St skyscraper. It appears to have been known as the Wynyard Building/s from ca 1893-94; from what I've been able to scape together I think the street address was 38-44 Carrington St...though changes in street numbering might be an issue here...I've never been able to track down an article on the skyscraper's construction...which is odd given it must have attracted attention at the time. Here's the newspaper report of the 1928 fire trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16434229 (pic of ruins on following page) ...better pics of the ruins acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=53247 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=53246 ; a few years later acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=53158

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per various digitised newspaper hits, Beil Grohn & Co appear to have been at 9 Wynyard St from late 1885 to mid 1889. They become insolvent in early 1889 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28338524 ; the building Beil Grohn & Co had occupied was up for lease as from July 1889 ('Store in Wynyard St', mid way down column 5 ) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13744825 ; there's also no scaffolding on the GPO tower, which suggests a date post ca. March 1886 (see comments here www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2554622065/) ; this 1885 North Australian advert refers to the band stand...evidently then a relatively recent addition nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47993886

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Note how pellethepoet's pics (above) show the Lang statue (unveiled in January 1891) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71248570 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=168539 ; the foundation stone was evidently laid in December 1888... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13706737 and presumably the pedestal would have been under construction sometime between then and the unveiling...but just going on PTP's pics, I'm not sure we'd see the pedestal in this pic, even if it were there...here's an ?1890s pic acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=413718 ...alas, these days the poor Reverend Doctor is marooned on a postage stamp PTP's 1st pic also shows the Henry Bull & Co building at 37 York St...completed in 1890...link parked here for possible future reference nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71183503 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=413675 another ?1890s pic...again with soot on the skyscraper's wall(!) ; www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=... Belmont House (shown here) just misses out on making it into the Hungerford Album pic

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] You might be wondering why the sudden extra interest in this photo - it is roughly contemporary with one of State Records NSW recently posted -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/9060549213/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I'd say you're correct re that dome...it looks to be either part of Her Majesty's Theatre, or part of the adjoining George Hotel (cnr Pitt & Market Sts), which evidently had 100ft frontage to Market St. www.flickr.com/photos/24785917@N03/2362696335/in/photolis... ...but I'm not sure it's the same mystery dome we see here www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8746028468/
